[edited jan 11] Welcome to the Signet Wallet Challenge. We will release this challenge this week (come to the welcome call to find out more details).

In the meantime, if you haven’t read [Mastering Bitcoin (make sure it’s the third edition)](https://github.com/bitcoinbook/bitcoinbook), you should start there. If you have, [here is a list of resources](https://bitcoindevs.xyz/learn) to get going with.  You can practice your [rust](https://btcdemy.thinkific.com/courses/intro-to-rust) or c++, get [philosophical](https://bitcoindevphilosophy.com), there is a [transaction tutorial](https://github.com/chaincodelabs/bitcoin-tx-tutorial), [Learn Bitcoin from the command line](https://github.com/BlockchainCommons/Learning-Bitcoin-from-the-Command-Line), read the [seminar materials](https://chaincode.gitbook.io/seminars) and more. Don’t let this time go unused, there is lots to learn. We can't wait to get started with you.

Here's a starter file for the first part of the challenge in C++ if anyone else wants.. I implemented hex_encode and hex_decode helpers for the Outpoint serialization functions but that's about the only change different from the rust file. I used the secp256k1 already a part of test-the-test bitcoin core as well.

Paste this below into your run_balance.sh, comment out the python/rust runs and then do ```sh solutions/run_balance.sh``` to run it.. your bitcoin_dir might also differ so change it accordingly lol

```# C++
# Using secp256k1 from test-the-test Bitcoin Core build
BITCOIN_DIR=~/Documents/GitHub/bitcoin-core-test-the-test-REPLACE_YOUR_GITHUB_HERE/bitcoin
SECP_INCLUDE="$BITCOIN_DIR/src/secp256k1/include" # Path to secp256k1 includes, resolves the secp256k1 headers
SECP_LIB="$BITCOIN_DIR/build/src/secp256k1/lib" # Path to secp256k1 library, resolves libsecp256k1.a

g++ -std=c++17 -O2 -o ./solution/cpp/balance ./solution/cpp/balance.cpp \
    -I"$SECP_INCLUDE" \
    -L"$SECP_LIB" \
    -lssl -lcrypto -lsecp256k1 2>&1

./solution/cpp/balance balance```

messages.content: Make sure you're using the right bitcoin.conf
I use the one present in /config/bitcoin.conf

```
REPO_ROOT := $(shell git rev-parse --show-toplevel)

start-deps:
    bitcoind -signet -conf=${REPO_ROOT}/config/bitcoin.conf -daemon

stop-deps:
    bitcoin-cli -signet stop
```

I used this ^Makefile to make my life easy
You're not. Otherwise you'd be in the right network
See the `-conf` bit in the Makefile I shared

Hi! Here, the notation indicates that the operation is performed under modulus n. In Zn, it does not make sense to apply the modulus operation to an individual element of the field, since all elements are already defined modulo n.

For example, when you see the secp256k1 curve equation (the one sent in the image), it is understood that all operations in the equation are performed modulo p. The notation used in the specification follows this same mathematical convention.

However what confuses me is this "the output key should commit to an unspendable script path instead of having no script path". I am not sure how is this aligning to what Bip 386 says:

"""
Specifically, "If the spending conditions do not require a script path, the output key should commit to an unspendable script path instead of having no script path. This can be achieved by computing the output key point as Q = P + int(hashTapTweak(bytes(P)))G." 
""" 

there is nothing related to "unspendable script path" thing in the math ` Q = P + int(hashTapTweak(bytes(P)))G`
no script path means that you just make Q = P
unspendable script path is the `int(hashTapTweak(bytes(P)))G`
Hmm got it. So no tweak in the former case

I think in that math, if you have Q being a valid spending path for some treehash, then you will arrive at 
- H(p) = H(p || treehash)
- or H(p + delta G || treehash) + delta = H(p) with delta != 0

It took me about 3 days to write a parser for the script descriptor. I was displeased with the documentation from here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/doc/descriptors.md

This is how I ended up writing a grammar, and started re-explaining the components of the descriptor: https://github.com/RazorBest/bitcoin-descriptor-spec

The grammar is written using Arpeggio (Python), and it also contains some semantic checks that validate the encodings and the value of the keys. If you've seen grammars before, it should be pretty easy to read, and treat the Python code as a technical documentation.
